contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the “vine” and the “fig tree” are symbols of prosperity. This phrase describes actions in which people live prosperously and in peace. If grapevines or fig trees are unknown you can translate this more generally. Alternate translation: “they will sit peacefully in their own gardens and fields” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they will sit every person under his vine and under his fig tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel used horses and chariots only in battle, and they may have traded for them with the godless nations around them. God did not want the people to trust in their weapons of war to protect them more than they trusted in him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will destroy your horses from among you and will demolish your chariots

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Balaam obeyed Balak by coming when Balak called him, Alternate translation: “how Balaam … did what Balak asked him to do” or (2) Balaam explained to Balak why Balaam had blessed the Israelites instead of cursing them as Balak had commanded. Alternate translation: “what Balaam told Balak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: how Balaam & answered him

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit the name of river. Alternate translation: “the Euphrates River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the River

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit the names of the seas. “from the Mediterranean Sea in the west to the Dead Sea in the east” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from sea to sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bashan and Gilead had been part of Israel long ago, when David was king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: as in the old days

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means he is from Moresheth which is a town in Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the Morashtite

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may want to make a footnote saying, “The name of this city means ‘house of dust.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Beth Leaphrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of this city sounds like one meaning “beautiful.” It contrasts with “nakedness and shame.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Shaphir

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name “Lachish” sounds like “to the chariots” in Hebrew. The people are hitching their chariots to flee, not fight. Lachish was the most important city after Jerusalem in Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Lachish

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may want to add a footnote saying “The name ‘Moresheth’ means ‘to depart.’ It is also similar in sound to the word for ‘fiancée.’” In this metaphor, Moresheth is the bride that Assyria takes, and the “parting gift” is the dowry, the gift her family gives for her to take into the marriage. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Moresheth Gath

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may want to make a footnote saying, “The name of this village sounds like the Hebrew word for ‘conqueror.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Mareshah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a royal city in Philistia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Adullam

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is either the name of the area in which Bethlehem was situated or it is just another name for Bethlehem or it distinguishes this Bethlehem from another. Bethlehem is about six miles south of Jerusalem. It was the hometown of King David. Translators may add this footnote: “The name ‘Ephrathah’ means ‘to be fruitful.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephrathah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another name for the land of Assyria. Nimrod was a hunter and early ruler. Translators may add this footnote: “The name ‘Nimrod’ means ‘rebellion.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: land of Nimrod

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of Balaam’s father. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Beor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these men were kings over the northern kingdom of Israel. God considered both of them to be very wicked. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Omri & Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: People under God’s judgment are expressing their grief in a strong way. Alternate translation: “I roll myself on the ground” or “I roll myself in the mud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I roll myself in the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israelites who were mourning would shave bald spots on their heads. This could mean: (1) “Shave larger spots than usual on your heads” or (2) “Cut off all your hair and shave your heads,” stating the events in the order in which they were to occur. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Shave your head and cut off your hair

contextId.occurrenceNote: They do this to show that they are ashamed of what they have done. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: They will put their hands on their mouths

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: This begins Micah’s prophecy. Micah speaks to the people of Samaria as if all the people of the earth and even the earth itself were able to hear him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen, all you peoples & isten, earth, and all that is in you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks to the people of Jerusalem by speaking to the temple mount as if it could hear him. You may need to make explicit that Micah is giving his message to the people. Alternate translation: “As for the temple mount, the place from which Yahweh watches over you, his sheep, the place that Jerusalem’s people are most proud of—its former dominion will return” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: As for you, watchtower for the flock, hill of the daughter of Zion—to you it will come, your former dominion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to the people of Judah, and especially to the people of Bethlehem, as if he were speaking to the town of Bethlehem itself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks to the people of Israel as if he were speaking to mountains that can hear him, so both instances of “listen” are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Now listen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks to the people of Israel as if he were speaking to mountains that can hear him, so both instances of “listen” are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen to Yahweh’s lawsuit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks to the people of the city, who can hear him, as if he were speaking to the city itself, which cannot hear him. You may need to make explicit the words that the ellipsis omits. Alternate translation: “I will make your city a ruin, and I will make you inhabitants an object of hissing” or “I will make you, city, a ruin, and I will cause everyone who sees you, inhabitants of the city, to hiss at you” or “I will make the city a ruin, and I will make people hiss at the inhabitants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make you, city, a ruin, and you inhabitants an object of hissing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the ruler descending from the ancient family of King David. The phrases “from ancient times” and “from everlasting” mean basically the same thing and emphasize how old this family line is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: whose beginning is from ancient times, from everlasting

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the “remnant of Jacob” will live in many different nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: among the nations, among many peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will go out” are understood from the previous phrase. They can be repeated here. Alternate translation: “and the word of Yahweh will go out from Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: and the word of Yahweh from Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “they will shepherd” are understood from the beginning of the sentence. They can be repeated. Alternate translation: “and they will shepherd the land of Nimrod” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: and the land of Nimrod

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “rises up” are understood from the previous phrase. They can be repeated here. Alternate translation: “a daughter-in-law rises up against her mother-in-law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are exaggerations. Alternate translation: “I feel as though faithful people have disappeared … land and there is no upright person … I feel as though they all lie in wait … blood, and each one hunts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: The faithful ones have disappeared & land; there is no upright person & They all lie in wait & blood; each one hunts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Snakes slither on the ground where dust gets on them, and here the people are being compared to snakes, though it is probably an exaggeration that they will lick the dust. This could mean: (1) will literally lie on the ground in shame or (2) will be so ashamed and humbled that it will be as if they were lying on the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: They will lick the dust like a snake

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to explain that a God gave a message to someone. Alternate translation: “the message that Yahweh spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh that came

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom makes explicit that the people will be totally naked. Alternate translation: “totally naked and ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in nakedness and shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: “from one mountain to another.” Micah does not speak of any particular mountain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from mountain to mountain

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Nothing anyone says will have any effect on them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: their ears will be deaf

contextId.occurrenceNote: “they will cry loudly.” They are pretending to mourn, as if those they love have died. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: lament with a wailing lamentation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the song that the enemies will sing to make fun of the Israelites and laugh as the Israelites suffer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: We Israelites & to traitors

contextId.occurrenceNote: This irony describes the king as having lost so much of his power and authority that he is really only a judge. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: the judge of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks as if Yahweh were a mighty soldier coming down from heaven and beginning to march on top of the mountains. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will come down and tread on the high places of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks as if Yahweh were a hot, solid object that melted the earth as it moved. Alternate translation: “He will crush the mountains and the valleys as he marches over them; he will destroy them, and they will completely disappear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The mountains will melt under him; the valleys will break apart, like wax before fire, like waters that are poured down a steep place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Samaria as if the city were a woman. Alternate translation: “Samaria … its stones … the foundations of the buildings in the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Samaria & her stones & her foundations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Samaria as if the city were a woman. Alternate translation: “the carved figures in the city … the gifts that people gave to the temple in the city … the idols in the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her carved figures & her gifts that she received & her idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people giving gifts to idols as if the people were hiring prostitutes. When the Assyrians destroy Samaria, they will take to Assyria the gifts the people of Samaria gave to their idols and give them as gifts to their own idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Since she gathered her gifts from the wages of prostitutes, they will become the wages of prostitutes again

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “her” refers to the city of Samaria. This means nothing can stop the enemy army from destroying the people who live there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For her wound is incurable

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah uses contagious disease as a metaphor for the army that Yahweh has sent to judge Samaria. Here “it” refers to the “wound,” that is, to the army that God will use to punish Samaria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for it has come to Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of punishing the people as if he were putting a yoke around their necks. Alternate translation: “from which you will not be able to escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from which you will not remove your necks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Reproach is spoken of as if it were a robber chasing a person. It can be translated as a verb. Alternate translation: “we will not allow you to reproach us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: reproaches must not come

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the wicked rich people are literally stealing robes from the poor or (2) creditors are keeping the outer garments of the poor who come to borrow money and give the garment as assurance they will repay. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You strip the robe, the garment, from those who pass by unsuspectingly

contextId.occurrenceNote: A butcher cutting up animals into meat is a metaphor for the leaders being cruel to the poor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you who tear off their skin, their flesh from their bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: A butcher cutting up animals into meat is a metaphor for the leaders being cruel to the poor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: just like meat in a cauldron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding the face is a metaphor for refusing to listen. Alternate translation: “He will turn his face away from you and cover it” or “You will see that he has no desire to help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will hide his face from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking on a good path is a metaphor for obeying God. Going astray from the path is a metaphor for disobeying God, in this case perhaps without knowing it. Alternate translation: “who lead my people to disobey me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who lead my people astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is using a metaphor to describe a situation that actually happens. The phrase “something to eat” is an ironic way of speaking of a small payment. Alternate translation: “they tell people who pay them even a small amount that things will go well for those people.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: if one gives them something to eat, they proclaim, ‘Peace.’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is using a metaphor to describe a situation that actually happens. The phrase “puts nothing in their mouths” is an ironic exaggeration for not giving what they want. Alternate translation: “they do all they can to destroy people who pay them too little” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: if he puts nothing in their mouths, they dedicate themselves to wage war on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Darkness is a metaphor for Yahweh not speaking to the prophets. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will be night for you & the day will be dark on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks of himself as if he were a container into which Yahweh were pouring a liquid. Alternate translation: “the Spirit of Yahweh has given me power, justice, and might” or “the Spirit of Yahweh has enabled me to be strong, to declare what justice is, and to be mighty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am full of power by the Spirit of Yahweh, and am full of justice and might

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Blood” here is a metonym for murder, and “Zion” and “Jerusalem” are spoken of as if they were buildings. Micah speaks of the rich murdering people and sinning in other ways as if those activities were the bricks and wood with which people use to build houses. Alternate translation: “You commit murder and other horrible sins as you work to make Zion and Jerusalem great” or “You commit murder as you worship in Zion, and you commit other sins as you get rich in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You build Zion with blood and Jerusalem with iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Zion” and “the hill of the temple” refer to the same place. When a farmer plows a field, he turns over all the dirt and uproots all the plants that are growing there. A thicket is so full of bushes that no one can use it for anything. These two metaphors cannot be literally true at the same time, but they emphasize that Yahweh will allow the invaders to completely destroy the temple area. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Zion will become a plowed field & and the hill of the temple will become a thicket

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh making the temple mount higher than all other mountains and hills is a metaphor for making his temple the most important place on earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the mountain & other mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: A stream flows continually to one place from many directions. Many people come to the temple mount from different directions. Alternate translation: “the people of the nations will flow like a stream to it” or “the people of the nations will go to it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: peoples will stream to it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his ways” and “his paths” refer to what God wants the people to do. “Walk” means they will obey what he says. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will teach us his ways, and we will walk in his paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: The law and the word going out is a metaphor for people hearing it and then being messengers to tell other people about it in other places. Alternate translation: “people will listen to the law in Zion and go out and tell others; they will listen to the word of Yahweh in Jerusalem and go out and tell others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from Zion the law will go out, and the word of Yahweh from Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking on a path is a metaphor for living one’s life. Walking in the name of someone is a metaphor for worshiping and obeying. Alternate translation: “the peoples … worship and obey their god … we will worship and obey Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the peoples walk & in the name of their god & we will walk in the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Jerusalem protecting the other people in surrounding areas is spoken of as if they were a shepherd in a watchtower watching over his flock. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: watchtower for the flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people who live in a place are spoken of as if the place is a mother and they are the daughter. Alternate translation: “people who live in Zion … people who live in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Zion & daughter of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people of Zion as if they were strong oxen about to thresh wheat and their enemies were the wheat. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise and thresh, daughter of Zion, for I will make your horn to be iron, and I will make your hooves to be bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your reader is not familiar with oxen or iron or bronze, you could remove the metaphor. Alternate translation: “for I will make you able to defeat and destroy every enemy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make your horn to be iron, and I will make your hooves to be bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of a city are spoken of as if they were a woman. The soldiers are attacking the city. Alternate translation: “people of the city, whom soldiers are attacking” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shepherd, who feeds and protects his sheep, is a metaphor for the ruler, who will provide for and protect the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will give him the strength to lead his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will stand and shepherd his flock in the strength of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “shepherds” is a metonym for “rulers,” another way of saying “leaders over men.” The phrase “seven … and eight” is an idiom for “more than enough.” Alternate translation: “enough, even more than enough, rulers” or “more than enough shepherds and leaders over men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: seven shepherds and eight leaders over men

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword is a metonym for killing in war. Here the Israelites ruling over the Assyrians is spoken of ironically as if they were killing sheep instead of herding them. The land of Assyria is a metonym for the people who live there. The entrances to cities were where official business took place. Alternate translation: “They will make war against the people of Assyria, and they will rule the cities of the land of Nimrod” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will shepherd the land of Assyria with the sword, and the land of Nimrod in its entrances

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Asherah poles as if they were trees that he would pull out of the ground. Alternate translation: “will pull your Asherah poles out of the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will uproot your Asherah poles

contextId.occurrenceNote: A house is a metaphor for a place in which one lives for a long time. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **bondage**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “to be slaves.” Alternate translation: “the place where you were slaves for a long time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: house of bondage

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “rod” refers to the enemy army with which Yahweh, who “has put it in place,” will discipline his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Pay attention to the rod, and to the one who has put it in place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rich men are spoken of as if they were containers, and people treating each other violently is spoken of as if it were a liquid that could be put into a container. Alternate translation: “The rich men act violently toward everyone” or “The rich men act violently all the time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The rich men are full of violence

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh striking his people with blows is a metaphor for him punishing them. Alternate translation: “I have punished you severely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strike you with a terrible blow

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person or thing being hungry is spoken of as if it were something that could be put in a container, and the people are spoken of as if they were containers. Alternate translation: “You will be hungry, and you will not be able to eat enough to satisfy yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your emptiness will remain inside you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking on a path is a metaphor for how a person lives his life. Alternate translation: “You do what Omri and Ahab told the people to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You walk by their advice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks of looking for faithful people but being unable to find any as if he were a person looking for food after the harvesters have taken it all. The idea of a person wanting to gather fruit can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I have become like someone looking for fruit after the gathering of summer fruit, like a gleaner after the grapes have been gleaned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I have become like the gathering of summer fruit, and like the grapes that have been gleaned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks of faithful, upright people as if they were fruit that is good to eat. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: no grape cluster & no ripe early fig

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood is a metaphor for the death of innocent people. Alternate translation: “to kill innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to shed blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are metaphors for suffering from disaster and then recovering. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: fall & rise

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are a metaphor for suffering from disaster. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: sit in darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rage is spoken of as if it were a solid object that Yahweh was forcing Micah to carry. Alternate translation: “I will suffer because he is angry with me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bear his rage

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were defending Micah in court. Alternate translation: “he defends me against those who harm me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he pleads my cause

contextId.occurrenceNote: Fruit is a metaphor for the results of an earlier action. Alternate translation: “because of the results of what they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: because of the fruit of their actions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is praying to Yahweh, asking him to protect his people of Israel again. Here “rod” refers to God’s leadership and guidance, as a shepherd uses a stick to guide and protect his sheep. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Shepherd your people with your rod, the flock of your inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks of his people as if they were wild animals hiding in bushes instead of livestock grazing in fields with much grass to eat. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They live alone in a thicket, in the midst of a pastureland

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” is a metonym for the people who live in many nations. Alternate translation: “The people of the nations nearby” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people are spoken of as if they were animals, because animals live in “dens.” Alternate translation: “their homes” or “their hiding places” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their dens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Iniquity and sin are spoken of as if they were solid objects. Alternate translation: “You will treat our iniquities and sins as if they were not important” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will trample our iniquities under your feet & ou will throw all our sins into the depths of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “because the people of Israel have sinned against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because of the sins of the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name “Jacob” is a metonym for those of his descendants who live in the northern kingdom of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: What is Jacob’s transgression?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Samaria” is a metonym for the evil activities that take place there. Micah uses a question to emphasize that the people know what the truth is. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You know that it is Samaria.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not Samaria?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” is a metonym for the evil activities that take place there. Micah uses a question to emphasize that the people know what the truth is. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You know that it is Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not Jerusalem?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “daughter” is a metonym for the people of the city. Alternate translation: “the people of Zion” or “the people who live in Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob’s descendants. Alternate translation: “descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lips” represents speaking. Alternate translation: “They shall no longer speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: All of them will cover their lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” and “Israel” are metonyms for Jacob’s descendants. Micah uses both names to emphasize that all of his descendants are guilty of sin. The abstract nouns “transgression” and “sin” can be translated using verbs. Alternate translation: “to declare to Jacob’s descendants that they have broken Yahweh’s law; I am telling the people of Israel that they have all sinned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: to declare to Jacob his transgression, and to Israel his sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob’s descendants. Alternate translation: “descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel’s descendants, who had become the nation of Israel. Alternate translation: “descendants of Israel” or “you Israelites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” is a metonym for the people of the nations. Alternate translation: “The people from many nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the word **hand** could mean: (1) it could be a metonym for the power that the hand exercises, Alternate translation: “the power of your enemies” or (2) it could be a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: “your enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The rod is a metonym for a greater man punishing a lesser man with a rod. To strike a man on the cheek was to insult him more than to harm him. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will punish the judge of Israel by having the invaders insult the judge of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: With a rod they strike the judge of Israel on the cheek

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person’s name is a metonym for person’s authority. Alternate translation: “and people will honor him because Yahweh his God has given him the authority to rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in the majesty of the name of Yahweh his God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises or a synecdoche for the whole person. To lift the hand is to exercise power. Alternate translation: “You will completely defeat your enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Your hand will be lifted against your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being in the “hand” represents the actions that the person does. Alternate translation: “the witchcraft that you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the witchcraft in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wisdom is spoken of as a person and is a metonym for the wise person. The word “name” here is a metonym for the person himself, what people think of him, and his authority. Alternate translation: “and the wise person will fear you” or “and the wise person will acknowledge that you are good and will obey you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: even now wisdom acknowledges your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dishonest wealth is a metonym for wealth that people have gained by acting dishonestly. The words “the wicked” refer to wicked people. Houses are a synecdoche for everything a person possesses. Alternate translation: “Wicked people have acted dishonestly to gain wealth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: There is wealth in the houses of the wicked that is dishonest

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. Alternate translation: “his own family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his own house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hear” represents hearing and acting. Alternate translation: “will act to help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will hear me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the names of Jacob and Abraham are metonyms for their descendants, the people of Israel to whom Micah was speaking. The abstract nouns “truth” and “faithfulness” can be stated as “trustworthy” and “faithful.” Alternate translation: “You will show the descendants of Jacob and Abraham that your are trustworthy and faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You will give truth to Jacob and covenant faithfulness to Abraham

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

God speaks through Micah to the people of Israel using poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks as if he is in court and the mountains and hills are the judges. He commands the people of Israel to tell the judges why they have done what they did. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise and state your case before the mountains; let the hills hear your voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is speaking to these things as if they are humans. Micah is using the mountains, hills, and foundations of the earth as an eternal witness against his people’s idolatry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: you mountains & you enduring foundations of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy mocks the surprise the rich leaders of Israel feel because God has taken their land and given it to someone else just as they had taken the land from the poor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “How wrong he is to take it from me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: How can he remove it from me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is scolding the Israelites by using this question. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You know that you do not need to ask … ‘Is the Spirit … his deeds?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should it really be said & “Is the Spirit & his deeds?”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the people really do not know if they are seeing Yahweh act. Alternate translation: “asked … ‘Is the Spirit of Yahweh angry? Are these really his deeds?’” or (2) the people do not believe that Yahweh is really punishing them. These rhetorical questions can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “said … ‘The Spirit of Yahweh is not really angry. These are not really his deeds.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: said & “Is the Spirit of Yahweh angry? Are these really his deeds?”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah uses a question to teach the people. It can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “My message does good to those who walk uprightly.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not my words do good to anyone who walks uprightly?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is scolding the leaders. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You act as though you think it is wrong for you to understand justice.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not right for you to understand justice?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders strongly believe that Yahweh is with them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We know that Yahweh is with us!” or “We know that Yahweh will help us do what we want to do!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is not Yahweh with us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is mocking the people, trying to make them think about why God is dealing with them in this way. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Look at how you are shouting loudly.” or “Think carefully about why you are shouting loudly.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Now, why do you shout so loudly?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah continues to mock the people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the idea behind these questionsas statements. Alternate translation: “You have a king, but he is useless to you. All your wise people are still alive, but they have nothing wise to say to you. This is why you are weeping loudly like a woman who is giving birth to a baby.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Is there no king among you? Has your counselor died? Is this why pain grips you like that of a woman in labor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses questions to emphasize that he is a good God, and he has done nothing to cause the people to stop worshiping him. Alternate translation: “My people, I have been good to you. I have done nothing to make you tired of me. If you think I have, testify against me, now.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: My people, what have I done to you? How have I wearied you? Testify against me!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks as if he were a person who truly wanted to know what God expects him to do. This could mean: (1) he asks questions and then in verse 8 answers the questions he has asked or (2) he is using questions to teach the people. Alternate translation: “I know that I do no need to bring to Yahweh … God, or come … old” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What should I bring to Yahweh & God? Should I come & old?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah continues to speaks as if he were a person who truly wanted to know what God expects him to do. This could mean: (1) he asks questions and then in verse 8 answers the questions he has asked or (2) he is using questions to teach the people. Alternate translation: “I know that Yahweh will not be pleased … oil or if I give … sin.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will Yahweh be pleased & oil? Should I give & sin?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “rams in groups of 1,000 … 10,000 rivers of oil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: thousands of rams & ten thousand rivers of oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I certainly will not consider a person innocent … weights.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should I consider a person to be innocent & weights?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy uses a question to mock the people of Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Yahweh your God cannot help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is Yahweh your God?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is emphasizing that there is no God like Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I know that there is no God like you, who takes … inheritance.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is a God like you—who takes & inheritance?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jackals and owls live in wastelands, and their loud cries sound like people wailing or weeping. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the jackals & like owls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah compares the suffering the people will experience when enemies force them away from their cities to the pain a woman experiences when giving birth to a baby. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Be in pain & like a woman in labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh being ready to destroy the nations as if Yahweh were a farmer who has put his bundles of grain on his threshing floor and is now ready to thresh them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: for he has gathered them like bundles of grain prepared for the threshing floor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dew and rain showers refresh the land and cause things to grow. The Israelites will cause the people among whom they live to live will. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like dew from Yahweh, like showers on the grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lions are able to kill and eat any wild animal of the forest, and they easily kill sheep. Alternate translation: “like the fiercest of wild animals, like a wild animal that kills helpless livestock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a lion among the animals of the forest, like a young lion among the flocks of sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Briers and thorns are good for nothing and harm those who touch them. The Israelite rulers and judges did nothing good and harmed people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The best of them is like a brier, the most upright is worse than a thorn hedge

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who walk on mud without thinking they are doing anything bad are compared with those who will destroy Israel’s enemies without thinking they are doing anything evil. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the mud in the streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “high place” is a synecdoche for the entire system of idol worship. “Judah” is a metonym for the people who live there. Alternate translation: “Where do the people of Judah go to worship idols?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: What is Judah’s high place?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The mouth is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh of hosts has spoken” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: for the mouth of Yahweh of hosts has spoken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to those who cannot walk well. Being lame is a synecdoche for having any form of disability. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the lame

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eye is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “let us gloat over Zion” or “let us enjoy watching the invaders destroy Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: let our eyes gloat over Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “you will destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: it will destroy them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tongue is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: “Everything they say is a lie” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: their tongue in their mouth is deceitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a synecdoche for the person. Alternate translation: “The people are very good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Their hands are very good

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase here refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “I” or “We” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: My eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh refers to himself by his own name. Alternate translation: “so that you may remember the righteous things that I, Yahweh, have done for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: so you may know the righteous acts of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “his” and “he” can be stated in second person. Alternate translation: “you … of the remnant of your inheritance, who do not keep your anger forever, because you delight in your covenant faithfulness?” or “you … of the remnant of your inheritance? You do not keep your anger forever, because you delights in your covenant faithfulness.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: you & of the remnant of his inheritance? He does not keep his anger forever, because he delights in his covenant faithfulness.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract noun **disaster** is spoken of here as a solid object rolling down a hill. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **disaster**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has caused bad things to happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: disaster has come down from Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **dominion**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “you will rule over the nations as you did before” or “I will make you rule over the nations as you did before” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: to you it will come, your former dominion

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wealth**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “the things that they own” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: their wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **workmanship**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “make.” Alternate translation: “what your hands have made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the workmanship of your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **kindness**, you can express the same idea with an adjective such as “kind.” Alternate translation: “love being kind to people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: love kindness

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **confusion**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “Now is when they do not understand what is happening” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Now is the time of their confusion

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “I will wait for the God who saves me” or “I will wait for God, who saves me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will wait for the God of my salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” Alternate translation: “he delights in being faithful to his covenant” or “he delights in being faithful to his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: he delights in his covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “I will break all her carved figures to pieces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: All her carved figures will be broken to pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “I will burn with fire all the gifts that she received” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: all her gifts & will be burned with fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “for I have taken away everything that might protect them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: for their protection is taken away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “for you disobeyed like the people of Israel did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: for the transgressions of Israel were found in you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “I will completely destroy it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: it is destroyed with complete destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “I will cause the seers to be ashamed, and I will confuse the diviners” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The seers will be put to shame, and the diviners will be confused

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will establish the mountain on which his temple is built” or “Yahweh will make the mountain on which his temple is built great” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the mountain of Yahweh’s house will be established

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will exalt it above the hills” or “Yahweh will make it higher than the hills” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: It will be exalted above the hills

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “I will turn” are understood from the previous phrase. They can be repeated. The phrase “the ones driven away” can be translated with an active verb. Alternate translation: “I will turn the ones I drove away into a strong nation” or “I will make the ones I forcefully sent away into a strong nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the ones driven away into a strong nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh says the same thing in both active and passive forms to emphasize that he will do what he has said he will do. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “There Yahweh will rescue you. There he will rescue you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: There you will be rescued & here Yahweh will rescue you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Let us defile her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Let her be defiled

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form, and you may need to supply the words that the ellipsis omitted. Alternate translation: “You have done what Omri commanded, and you have done the same things the house of Ahab did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The regulations made by Omri have been kept, and all the deeds of the house of Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks to the people of Israel, so both instances of “your” are plural. The word “watchmen” is a metaphor for prophets. Alternate translation: “Their prophets have told them that Yahweh would punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It is the day foretold by your watchmen, the day of your punishment

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “her enemies will trample her down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: she will be trampled down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will greatly extend the boundaries of your land” or “Yahweh will greatly increase the size of your kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the boundaries will be extended very far

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “us” refers to Micah and the people, but not to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: on us

contextId.occurrenceNote: These nominal adjectives can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “hate everything that is good and love everything that is evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: hate good and love evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speakers are speaking to Micah and to others, so this is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not prophesy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is speaking to the people of Judah, so both instances of “you” are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: comes to you & will prophesy to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “the people would consider him” or “you would consider him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: he would be considered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah is speaking to some of the descendants of Jacob, so the word “you” is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: all of you, Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Come

contextId.occurrenceNote: All instances of “your” and “you,” as well as the commands, refer to the “daughter of Zion” and so are singular and feminine. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise and thresh, daughter of Zion & your horn & your hooves & You will crush

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer is speaking to Yahweh, so both instances of “your” are masculine singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Your hand & your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking to the people of Israel as if they were one man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your horses & among you & your chariots

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking to the people of Israel as if they were one man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your land & your strongholds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel as if they were one man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your hand & you will

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel as if they were one man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your carved & your stone & among you & ou will & your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel as if they were one man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your Asherah & among you & your cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah speaks to the people of Israel as if they were one man, so the commands and the word “your” are singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise & state

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to the people as if they were one man, so all instances of “you” and all the commands are masculine singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: to you & wearied you? Testify

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to the people as if they were one man, so all instances of “you” and all the commands are masculine singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: brought you & rescued you & Miriam to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to the people as if they were one man, so all instances of “you” and all the commands are masculine singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: remember & you went & you may know

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Micah speaks to the people of Israel as if he were speaking to one man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: You will

dublin_core.creator: Door43 World Missions Community
dublin_core.description: Open-licensed exegetical notes that provide historical, cultural, and linguistic information for translators. It provides translators and checkers with pertinent, just-in-time information to help them make the best possible translation decisions.
dublin_core.subject: TSV Translation Notes
dublin_core.title: unfoldingWord® Translation Notes

index.name: Making Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information Explicit
Singular Pronouns that refer to Groups
